citation.article-title: Amphibacillus xylanus gen. nov., sp. nov., a facultatively anaerobic sporeforming xylan-digesting bacterium which lacks cytochrome, quinone, and catalase.

p.s: Amphibacillus (Am. phi. ba. cil' lus. Gr. pref. amphi, both sides or double; L. dim. n. bacillus, a small rod; M. L. masc. n. Amphibacillus, rod capable of both aerobic and anaerobic growth)
Cells are rods that are 0.3 to 0.5 μm in diameter and 0.9 to 1.9 μm long.
Gram positive in the very early stages of growth and loosely gram positive in stationary growth phase.
Heat resistant, oval endospores are formed, but the sporangia are rapidly lysed and the spores are liberated.
Spores are formed under both aerobic and anaerobic conditions.
Grows well both in well-aerated cultures and in aerobic cultures (Eh,-370 mV; pH 10) when titanium(III) citrate is used as a reducing agent.
Does not grow in nutrient broth.
Produces ethanol, acetic acid, and formic acid under anaerobic conditions and acetic acid under aerobic conditions from glucose (9).
Grows at pH values between 8.0 and 10.0 but not at pH 7.0.
Contains meso-diaminopimelic acid in the cell wall, and the peptidoglycan structure is the direct-linkage type which corresponds to type A1γ of Schleifer and Kandler (11).
The major cellular fatty acids are anteiso- and iso-branched and straight-chain acids.
Cytochromes, isoprenoid quinones, catalase, and oxidase are not detected.
The DNA base composition ranges from 36 to 38 mol% G+C.
Probably widely distributed in composts of manure with grass.
The type species is Amphibacillus xylanus.
